segments.text: ओम ज्ञानति मिरान्धस्या ज्ञानान् जनिषलाकया चक्षुरण्मीरितं येना दस्मै श्री गुरवे नमः नमाः ओम विष्णु पादाया कृष्ण प्रेष्ठाय भूतले श्री मते भक्ति वेदान्त स्वामिन्निति नामिने नमस्ते सारस्वते देवे गवरवाणी �

The meaning of this verse is, while outside observing her husband who will burn in the fire of mystic power along with his thatched cottage,
his chaste wife Gandhari will enter the fire with rapt attention.
So, now already Narada has told Yudhishthira, Dhritarashtra will follow the yogic process and quit the body and the body will be burnt by the self-generated fire through the mystic power.
Now, along with Dhritarashtra's body burning, the thatched cottage in which he was sitting and performing his,
austerity or the practice itself will burn.
And what will Gandhari do?
She is not practicing any yoga.
She is just faithfully as a chaste wife following her husband.
So, Srila Prabhupada explains, Gandhari was an ideal chaste lady, a life companion of her husband.
And therefore, when she saw her husband burning in the fire of mystic yoga along with his cottage of leaves, she despaired.
Naturally, wife is very faithfully serving the husband and the husband quits, it's a big loss for the wife because she has always been with him as a chaste wife and she has been serving him.
Now, what will she do when he is no longer present in the form as the husband?
So, it says here, Srila Prabhupada explains,
She left home after losing her husband.
So, it says here, Srila Prabhupada explains, She left home after losing her husband.
So, it says here, Srila Prabhupada explains,
She left home after losing her 100 sons and in the forest she saw that her most beloved husband was also burning.
She lost her sons in the battle of Krukshetra.
Our husband also, he quit his body which was a self-generated fire, through mystic yoga practice.
What will she do?
So, Prahpa says, Now she actually felt alone and followed her husband to death.
So, Prahpa says, Now she actually felt alone and followed her husband to death.

pure devotee. Why? Why Vidhara could not make Dhritarashtra pure devotee? Because Dhritarashtra was inimical to the Pandavas who were all devotees of the Lord. Therefore Vidhara could not make Dhritarashtra pure devotee.

An offence at the feet of a Vaishnava is more dangerous than an offence at the feet of the Lord. Vidhara was certainly very liberal to bestow mercy upon Dhritarashtra whose past life was very materialistic but ultimately the result of all such mercy depends on the will of the Lord who grants spiritual advancement, who grants spiritual liberation, who grants spiritual benefits.
It's only the will of the Lord.

It's only the Lord. Devotees may help, devotees may guide, devotees may direct, devotees may inspire but devotees cannot give anything. It is the Lord only who gives. Lord is completely under the control, in control of a spiritual potency and by spiritual potency the Lord gives spiritual advancement, spiritual benefits, spiritual liberation, spiritual
engagement, everything.

So Dhritarashtra attained liberation only but Vidhara, sorry Dhritarashtra can, Dhritarashtra attained liberation only but he can attain the stage of devotional service after many many many such liberated states of life.
So, bahu nam janma namante dhyana vanamaam prapadyate.
One is able to properly surrender to Krishna only after many many lifetimes of living that stage of liberation.
In proper understanding of one's spiritual identity, in relationship with Krishna.

That relationship means, repenting, breathing in words, expressing self forced deeds, confession of great freedom in the spiritual realm, and knowing the divine gift and the real spiritual power, logging into the terms and forms of existence of our forest.

no more inimical feeling towards devotees or the Supreme Lord.
The last verse of this chapter, sixtieth verse,
ityuktvā atha āruhat svargam nārada sahatumburuhu
yuriṣṭiro vachastasya hṛdī pritvā jahā chuchah
The meaning of this last verse, sixtieth verse is,
Having spoken thus, the great sage Nārada, along with his veena, ascended into outer space.
Yuriṣṭira kept his instruction in his heart and so was able to get to the fall lamentation.
Yuriṣṭira was lamenting that my uncle left home and went away. I don't know where he has gone.
Nārada informed him where Dhritarashtra has gone.
Nārada informed him what will happen to Dhritarashtra.
That Dhritarashtra will be liberated.
And therefore, Yuriṣṭira, keeping the instruction of Nārada in his heart,
he became free from all lamentation.
Now, Nārada is described here by Prabhupāda as an eternal spaceman.
He is having a spiritual body, endowed by the Supreme Lord himself.
He can travel in outer space of both the material and the spiritual worlds.
He is free to travel anywhere.
Without any restrictions.
And he can approach any planet, either in the material world or the spiritual sky.
Spiritual sky are the Vaikuntha Lokas.
In the material world, there are different kinds of upper planetary systems.
Svarga Loka, Maharloka, Janaloka, Tapoloka, Brahmaloka, or the earthly planets.
Bhūloka, Bhūvarloka, or even the lower planets, Atala, Vitala, Sutala, anywhere he can go.
And why does he travel?
He simply travels to preach the message of Kṛṣṇa about bhakti and to deliver people, to liberate people from material bondage.
So, one should try to follow in the footsteps of Nārada Muni and not make any attempt to go to some heavenly planets by some material activities.
No.
You should follow in the footsteps of Nārada Muni.
Become a devotee and go back to the spiritual kingdom of Kṛṣṇa.
That's where we belong.
And there, in the spiritual kingdom, engage in loving devotional service with no possibility of again taking birth in this material world.
So, that's the instruction given by Śrīla Prabhupāda in this book.
I'll stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Kṛṣṇa.
